title: Criminal Probe Opened in Deadly Boat Fire
text:
Authorities served search warrants Sunday at the office of Truth Aquatics, the Conception’s owner.

Federal authorities have initiated a criminal probe into last week’s deadly dive-boat disaster in Southern California that killed 34, law-enforcement officials said Monday.

As part of the probe, authorities served search warrants Sunday at the office of Truth Aquatics, the Santa Barbara company that owned the Conception, the boat that caught fire and sank during a diving expedition to the Channel Islands, a spokesman for the Santa Barbara County Sheriff said. They also searched two other boats belonging to the company.

The probe, which is focused on safety issues, is being conducted by several agencies including the Coast Guard, U.S. Attorney’s Office, Federal Bureau of Investigation and the Bureau of Alcohol Tobacco Firearms and Explosives, the officials said.

A spokesman for Truth Aquatics said the company couldn’t comment because of the ongoing investigations. The Los Angeles Times first reported on the investigation.

description: Investigators served search warrants to the owner of the Conception, on which 34 people died.
